reviewText: Perry Mason Season 1 Volume 1These TV films from 1957 are mostly the simplified and condensed versions of the original novels. The books are more complete and informative but the films still tell stories about life that is not experienced by most people. The books can tell you why certain things are done, the films only show you what happened (when Paul Drake takes the next sheet of a telegraph message pad). The books tell you about "ropers", rough or smooth shadows, and how to evade surveillance and avoid leaving a back trail. Some may question the legality and ethics of Perry Mason's tactics but most stories were written before the modern legal rules of the 1960s. The backgrounds tell about life in Los Angeles. It is difficult to film a scene at night but easy to describe it in a book. Erle Stanley Gardner was the founder of the "Court of Last Resort" which sought to free many unjustly convicted persons. Gardner, among others, sought to use scientific means to find the guilty, rather than using hunches or guesses alone.Some of the stories and names were changed for TV. The theme music is typical for the late 1950s. Note the style of clothing and culture; ladies wore white gloves. People seldom lock their doors. The prices date these films. One advantage is seeing the many automobiles from the 1950s. How many can you identify? Note the slimness of people then, and the casual handling of pistols. Smoking was very common [a tobacco sponsor]. Watch how the actors express their emotions by their facial expressions. The camera sharpness and quality is excellent on these films. There is nothing like these entertaining and dramatic stories on today's broadcast TV. When was the last time you saw a trial lawyer as a hero? These stories often use the misinterpretation of circumstantial evidence to provide dramatic effects. If a girl's clothing is found in the apartment of a murdered man what does that prove? The question is how the clothing or fingerprints got there. The courtroom scenes are usually the Preliminary Hearings (to save the cost of extra actors). This are the titles of the 19 stories with the year of the novel. Note how many years were used in one year of the series. All titles begin with "The Case of the ".Restless Redhead (1954) 09/21/57; Sleepwalker's Niece (1936) 09/28/57;Nervous Accomplice (1955) 10/05/57; Drowning Duck (1942) 10/15/57.Sulky Girl (1933) 10/19/57;  Silent Partner (1940) 10/26/87;Angry Mourner (1957) 11/02/57;  Crimson Kiss (1971) 11/09/57.Vagabond Vixen (1948) 11/16/87;  Runaway Corpse (1954) 11/23/57;Crooked Candle (1944) 11/30/57;  Negligent Nymph (1950) 12/07/57.Moth-Eaten Mink (1952) 12/14/57; Baited Hook (1940) 12/21/57;Fan Dancer's Horse (1947) 12/28/57; Demure Defendant (1956) 01/04/58.Sun Bather's Diary (1955) 01/11/58; Cautious Coquette (1949) 01/18/58;Haunted Husband (1941) 01/25/58.

reviewText: I enjoyed the Perry Mason series as a child; they were part of a family tradition which included visits to family friends so my parents could play cards together and so the children of both families could watch their favorite television programs.  When I saw the series offered on DVD, I decided to purchase some of them.  I'm so glad I did.  I actually get much more out of them now than I did at the time.It's amazing to see how much of US culture has changed over time; it's also impressive to see how much television has contributed to it.  While I, having lived through it, have felt that things "haven't changed much" technologically, in fact they really have!  Seeing the old television sets, the automobiles, the typewriters, etc. makes me realize how "primitive" we were back then.  More than that, even, is the very obvious lack of convenient devices that we enjoy now.  When Paul Drake had to stop by a phone booth to call Perry in two different episodes, I realized how instant our communications have become in recent times.Our society has changed a lot in other ways, too.  While it was nice seeing men open doors for women, etc. the attitude of "woman the helpless" gets pretty tiresome.  Seeing their overwhelming dependence on men, the legal and sociological obstacles that prevented its being any other way, made me realize how far our society has come in leveling the playing field between the genders.  Seeing the incredible burdens placed on men during those times makes me realize that equalizing that playing field in the interest of a more collaborative relationship was probably good for both men and women.  Seeing where the country had started with respect to ethnic and racial attitudes and to their liberalization through the medium of television was also interesting.  While Perry Mason was hardly in the front lines of social reform--black people are always in the background where they appear at all--the presentation of Asians in a positive light, especially so soon after World War II, suggests a trend was already starting in the very early 60s.Probably most importantly to the average person is the major change in our legal system.  While I enjoy Perry's overwhelming belief in and loyalty to his clients and his capacity to see through to the real culprit, I still cringe when he tampers with evidence and aids his clients in their evasion of the law.  I also cringe when I see the rather cavalier handling of evidence by the police; it makes one wonder how many people were convicted by virtue of such bungling!  I think that our more recent expectation that there be a clear "history" of the handling of evidence is a very positive and necessary one.The one tradition that appears to be solid from Perry's time to ours is the rule of law and its mediation by both clear standards and past practice.  While justice may be misdirected by adherence to these principles, it is only by maintaining them without fail for everyone, that anything like justice can be served.  If nothing else, the system makes at least an attempt, to the best of human abilities, to serve the interests of society and of the individuals within it.  Inequities occur, but here as in other human endeavors, it's the attempt that counts.  That's a good lesson.
summary: Nostolgia but a lesson in social change too

reviewText: This is the first half-season's worth of "Perry Mason," the classic 1957-66 CBS legal series created by Erle Stanley Gardner, and starring Raymond Burr as the title character, a criminal defense attorney in L.A. Mason's practice included a loyal secretary, Della Street (Barbara Hale), and an equally-loyal investigator, Paul Drake (William Hopper). In each outing (19 included in this first release), a murder (which was usually the chosen crime) is perpetrated, and several suspects are involved. Perry and his team go to work sleuthing and uncovering evidence to use in the trial (in most episodes) of the person whom D.A. Hamilton Burger (William Talman) believes committed the crime. Perry, however, has various tricks up his sleeve and aces in the hole that prove that not only did the original defendant not commit the crime, but a related person could in fact have committed it (said related person or people then being bound over at the end for trial). In doing so, he makes a punny name of his adversary Burger (i.e. he makes Ham Burger [get it?!] of his opponent).The reason why there are only 19 outings in this first release (and why the series was released in volumes to begin with) is because back at the time that "Mason" was originally on more than 50 years ago, television seasons were much, much longer than they are now (usually 30-40 outings for both dramas and comedies). The individual outings that made up these longer seasons were longer in and of themselves as well (50-52 min. for hour series such as this, with 8-10 min. of commercials; nowadays, we only get 40-odd min. of content, almost 20 of commercials). The 19 outings of this first release are contained on 5 discs (four each on the first four, 3 on the last). Each outing is uncut and maintains its original running time; not only that, each outing is remastered and looks quite brand-new on DVD (notwithstanding some grain). The discs are contained in three slipcases (two in the first two, one in the last); the outings are described on the back of each case.One of the major hallmarks of "Mason" is that fact that all outings were defined as "The Case of _________." There were quite a few series after that used similar keywords to define their outings, but as far as I can recall, "Mason" was the pioneer of such titling.Another is that it used what, it has been said, was one of television's finest title tracks--"Park Avenue Beat" by Fred Steiner, which ran the full original run, and was rerecorded for a series of reunion films (most of which Burr starred in) from 1985-95 on NBC.In short, albeit this is only the first part of #1, this is still a must-have release, if only for the fact that "Mason" is one of the classics of the medium, and remains so more than 50 years after it started (close to 50 after it ended).

reviewText: Perry Mason was certainly the finest courtroom drama ever on television. It was entertainment that kept viewers glued to their seats, waiting for that moment when Perry would nail the killer on the witness stand and free his client.Raymond Burr had some good roles in films, but will always be remembered for the tough defense attorney you wanted on your side in the toughest jam. Barbara Hale was his pretty secretary, Della Street, who kept Perry human and was in love with him. William Hopper was the dapper detective, Paul Drake. He had a playful and flirtatious relationship with Della but every viewer knew that secretly her heart belonged to Perry.William Talman as D.A. Hamilton Burger was the perfectly cast guy you almost felt sorry for, as just when he was ready to gloat over his victory in court, Perry would spring his client by revealing the real killer, once again defeating poor old Burger. The relationship of these four people made the mood and mystery of the often gripping conclusion fun to watch. There has never been anything close to it in genre on television since. Its mix of drama, noir, and humor, and its truly likable characters, made for terrific viewing.Earle Stanley Gardner's original creation of Perry Mason was a bit more two-fisted pulp type reading, but slowly grew into something resembling the show when it became so popular. Gardner's Perry Mason novels, begun decades before the show and continuing for decades more, are still fun to read. The same can be said of every single show in the series.The first season, unlike many shows, hit its stride immediately, and remained top-notch television for many years. Like the novels, the title of every episode began with "The Case of-" and each one had some wonderful moments, both in and out of the courtroom. Only the first 19 episodes are included in this 5 disc set, with the next 20 coming soon. The episodes for season one, all 39 of them, beginning in the fall of 1957 and ending in 1958, are as follows:THE CASE OF THE------- Restless Redhead -- Sleepwalker's Niece -- Nervous Accomplice -- Drowning Duck -- Sulky Girl -- Silent Partner -- Angry Mourner -- Crimson Kiss -- Vagabond Vixen -- Runaway Corpse -- Crooked Candle -- Negligent Nymph -- Moth-Eaten Mink -- Baited Hook -- Fan-Dancer's Horse -- Demure Defendant -- Sun Bather's Diary -- Cautious Coquette -- Haunted Husband -- Lonely Heiress -- Green-Eyed Sister -- Fugitive Nurse -- One-Eyed Witness -- Deadly Double -- Empty Tin -- Half-Wakened Wife -- Desperate Daughter -- Daring Decoy -- Hesitant Hostess -- Screaming Woman -- Fiery Fingers -- Substitute Face -- Long-Legged Models -- Gilded Lily -- Lazy Lover -- Prodigal Parent -- Black-Eyed Blonde -- Terrified Typist -- Rolling BonesYou can't beat this for entertainment, any more than Hamilton Burger could beat Perry Mason in court. reviewText: One of the things I love about Amazon is that here one can find others with a passion for the same tiny slices of pleasure that life may offer. It's wonderful to find myself among grateful Perry Mason fans. I can offer little here that will illuminate the series better than anyone else who has written about it. Suffice it to say that I have been putting in a search on Amazon for this show for the past few years, and when it finally came up "Yes!" a couple of months ago, I was thrilled. This is why some of us collect DVD's: to have the opportunity of owning and reliving the joys of some of the best that film and television had to offer.I offer a personal anecdote here to illustrate what this series meant to me. As a young boy, two of my passions were acting and solving mysteries. I assuaged one passion by taking part in theatrical productions in school and the community and the other by reading voraciously, first the Hardy Boys and then the entire Agatha Christie canon (followed by Ellery Queen, John Dickson Carr and the like.) And then there was Mason, who could always be counted on at the end of an episode to begin an innocent cross-examination of a witness and then pounce with, "Isn't it true....?" By the time Perry had made mincemeat of the suspect, a confession was guaranteed.  (Oh, what joy it must have been for the actors who learned that they would get to deliver a dramatic mea culpa!) When I informed my parents at an early age that I wanted to be an actor, Mom and Dad, who had hoped for an attorney in the family, suggested that I "be an actor like Perry Mason" (in other words, a lawyer.) I held onto that career goal through college, but after realizing that the legal system is nothing like TV, that most defendants are not innocent, I eventually turned toward other pursuits, like teaching and directing. Still, Perry Mason will always remain not only one of the top ten shows (which I will collect with a vengeance and watch in order with great joy) but a reminder of a life I thought I wanted...and would have grabbed at with gusto if only it were real.

reviewText: The first two years of PM were the best -- snappy, witty dialogue, lots of action, intricate plots, and a wonderful snapshot of 50's mores and attitudes (e.g. everybody drinks and smokes, guys wear great-looking hats, "bad girls" are announced by a smoky sax on the soundtrack).  As the years went on, Perry himself became stodgier, as did the storylines.  The wonderfully crusty Ray Collins was never adequately replaced as Lt. Tragg, but Bill Talman as Hamilton Burger hung in there until the end, and was the perfect foil for Raymond Burr.  And don't overlook Barbara Hale's Della Street, the sexiest secretary in the history of TV; the early years showed Perry and Della as surprisingly intimate partners, e.g. cooking steaks and tossing salad at Perry's apartment, or Della giving the exhausted Perry a shoulder rub.  At times,  Della seemed to have a LOT more on her mind than legal writs when she looked at Perry with those wonderfully expressive eyes ...The transfer to DVD looks stunning, and it's wonderful to have the episodes released in their original order.  But I'm disappointed that there's no commentary included.  When Columbia House released about half the episodes on VHS several years ago, they included notes on the guest stars and other fun trivia.  But except for that small complaint, this is a great boon to PM fans.  I can hardly wait for Volume 2!

reviewText: From the stirring music to the brilliant acting, Perry Mason remains one of the best courtroom dramas ever produced, even though it was one of TV's earliest.Based on the successful books by Erle Stanley Gardner, the production quality of the series was so high that the many of the episodes have the feeling of a movie, or as some reviewers have noted, true film noir.Debuting in 1957, Perry Mason ran for nine seasons and became a part of popular culture. It propelled its star, Raymond Burr, into the status of an icon, even though he already had a distinguished career as a movie actor, ironically primarily playing bad guys. In Mason, Burr brought incredible depth, quick intelligence and an amazing robust energy that remains as fresh today as it was almost 50 years ago!The first season had 39 episodes, 19 of which are being released in this DVD boxed set, while the remaining 20 will be released in Season One, Volume 2.In addition to Burr, the stellar cast includes Barbara Hale, who portrays Mason's devoted secretary, Della Street; William Hopper as Mason's private investigator Paul Drake; William Talman as the perennially losing District Attorney Hamilton Burger; and Ray Collins, as the acerbic but honest Lt. Arthur Tragg.Although Mason often acted as an investigator, won all but one of his cases, and he managed to evoke witness stand confessions from the majority of the guilty parties, the show still managed to convey a courtroom realism seldom seen, and is still often sadly missing in modern TV series dealing with crime and punishment.The crimes were believable because they were drawn from the realistic fodder of real life conflicts and temptations, not the twisted and often sadistic crimes that are too often shown on TV today on current courtroom dramas.Even though the series began in the 50's, it hinted at a more-than-platonic relationship between Mason and Street. The bantering that the two actors brought to their roles heightened the tension between them on the show and is still wonderful to watch. In real life, the two were very close friends and remained so until his untimely death from cancer. Burr, a nationally renowned amateur horticulturist, named a specific type of orchid that he had developed after Hale. reviewText: Erle Stanley Gardner (1889-1970) began his own career as a lawyer--but his own legal career was quickly overshadowed by Perry Mason, a fiction attorney Gardner created in 1933.  The character would be the subject of numerous novels, motion pictures, radio programs, made-for-television movies, and most famously a television series that ran from 1957 to 1966.In a certain sense, PERRY MASON episodes are pure formula.  The first portion of the program sets up a questionable situation that drives a character to seek aid from Mason.  The murder generally occurs after Mason has accepted the client, who now finds the situation going from bad to worse and who is accused of the murder.  There follows a hearing or trial at which Mason proves the client innocent and exposes the real killer--very often on the witness stand.  While the structure is repetitive, and although it is a bit much that Mason never seems to lose a case and the killer almost always cracks under cross examination, the repetitive nature of the episodes and the inevitable climax is part of what makes the show fun and entertaining.  You know that Perry will win, you just don't know how and who.The series is also notable for exceptional production values.  Television programs of the 1950s and 1960s were often cheaply made, but PERRY MASON was not: it was filmed on high-grade celluloid on location and meticulously rendered sets, and the classic black and white look makes the series seem very noir-ish.  The script had a driving quality and often mixed dry wit with drama, the music was spectacularly memorable, and the regular cast was nothing short of flawless.  Raymond Burr (1917-1993), Barbara Hale (b. 1922), William Hopper (1915-1970), William Talman (1915-1968) and Ray Collins (1889-1965) were not stars, but they had solid bodies of work before they came to the series--and they played exceptionally well, with the chemistry between Burr, Hale, and Hopper particularly enjoyable.  Episodes also often featured actors who would go on to become famous, with Frances Bavier ("Aunt Bea" of the Andy Griffin Show) and Barbara Eden ("Jeannie" of I Dream of Jeannie) cases in point.PERRY MASON SEASON ONE VOLUME ONE includes 19 episodes.  Each of the is enjoyable; if I were pressed to name favorites, however, I would probably pick "The Case of The Drowning Duck," which is somewhat atypical of the series, and "The Case of the Crimson Kiss," which has a particularly inspired plot twist.  But all of them are tremendous fun and greatly entertaining.  Recommended.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

reviewText: I was too young to see Perry Mason in its early days, and I knew better than to watch it when episodes were syndicated as they would be cut to provide for more commercials. Watching it now many years after it was made, this series more than holds up. Although it is true that today Mason would not be allowed to do some of the things he does in the episodes of this series, every episode has excellent acting, the scripts are great, and the the show still works.It was always a joke that Mason won every case, while the lawyers in other shows (The Defenders as an example) lost some. That wasn't why you watched Perry Mason. Certainly the camaraderie among Burr, Hale and Hopper counted for a lot, and the stories were always interesting and kept the viewer's interest. It helped that the creator of Mason was a master mystery writer who oversaw the show and got what he wanted.It is also true as one reviewer pointed out that Mason and Della Street look like they certainly have something going on based on how they interact. I wonder how many viewers noticed this back in 1957. It is certainly hard to miss now; Burr and Barbara Hale certainly have sparks going on between them, a real chemistry. It is hardly surprising that they were great friends in real life, and Burr demanded that she return when he revisited the character in made-for-TV movies long after the series was cancelled.There is another element that I didn't remember, and is clearly evident. Both the Burger and Trask characters not only disliked Mason, they loathed him, often setting him up and trying to deliberately trick him so that he could get into his own legal troubles. Like a master chess player, Mason plays them with his logic and skills, and both not only look bad, but they look like idiots, which doesn't stop them from trying again week after week. Trask even says in one of the episodes from the first season that he thinks Mason is a lot of things, but that he is not stupid.Unlike some other vintage television series, the quality is first-rate. These are new prints struck from the 35MM negatives, and rarely have a mark on them. They are a joy to watch, as is this series.

reviewText: It's quite remarkable how Perry Mason has held up over the years, especially when compared to the current run of lawyer/law shows we've been bombarded with lately.The secret was in the wonderful casting of established acting veterans.  Burr, Hopper, Hale, Talman, & Collins are in perfect sync from the very first episode. It certainly looks like they were having a ball acting with each other during this time as well."Perry Mason" is clearly a creation of it's time which is actually part of it's charm. There's hardly a moment when someone is not smoking on screen (William Hopper in particular) and everyone seems dressed to the nines at times. And while much has been made of how Hamilton Burger could keep his D.A. job after losing to Mason so many times, I wonder just how Lt. Tragg could still be a lieutenent at his rather advanced age.One aspect of the series that always made me laugh was how finding a corpse was no big deal.  In "The Case of Baited Hook", the dead body literally falls in front of Perry and Paul and gets absolutely NO reaction.The presentation of the episodes are from the original masters, including the sponsors' logos at the end of some of the episodes. Curiously, colorized photos of Perry are used on the box covers, why I have no idea since every episode save one (during the final season) was presented in black and white.I've subracted one star from my review because of the total lack of extras. While cast interviews are probably out of the question (as of this date, Barbara Hale is the only major cast member still alive from the first season and she's well into her 80's), we could've had much simpler fare like production notes, trivia, original Perry Mason promos if they existed, etc.Anyway, this set is sure to delight fans of this timeless series and I'm looking forward to the next set with great anticipation.Tidbits:- In the Gardner novels, there is no physical description of Perry Mason. Nor is there anything made of Perry's relationship with Della.- As the legend goes, Gardner himself selected Raymond Burr upon seeing his tryout yelling "That's him, that's Perry Mason!".- Raymond Burr's agent was the one who suggested he try out for the Hamilton Burger role first (probably because Burr was most noted for being the "bad guy" in his movie roles).  But Burr insisted that he also be allowed to try out for Mason.- Most of the time, we know when Perry is about to appear in an episode because his "theme" music starts playing.- Perry's famous convertable does not appear until the second episode.- It's pretty clear in the episode "The Case of Demure Defendant" that in the long shots of Perry's convertable on the way to Logan City that someone other than Raymond Burr is driving the car.- A cute moment happens during "The Case of Fan Dancer's Horse" when both "fan dancers" are asked to stand side by side in the courtroom. Just look for a priceless gaze at their "assets" by Paul Drake.- Doesn't it seem odd that Perry, given his income, would live in an apartment? Although this one does have a fireplace.

reviewText: Decades before the likes of Matlock, Law & Order and Boston Legal, television hosted an American icon in the fictional character of the granddaddy of all TV lawyers, Perry Mason. This determined defense attorney, first penned by Erle Stanley Gardner and so vividly brought to life by Raymond Burr, did for lawyers what Joe Friday did for police officers; he made the profession respectable. In today's grey-area legal dramas, one won't find the black-and-white morals that fit so well with the cinematography, but they are a comfort to view again on DVD in all of their crisp and splendid restorations.Each episode is comfortably formulaic in its set-up and execution. A client always comes to Perry Mason to consult him over some legal difficulty. Inevitably, the client finds him/herself accused of a murder; a murder of which they are unquestionably innocent. With the help of his girl Friday secretary, Della Street (Barbara Hale), and his favorite suave private detective, Paul Drake (William Hopper), Perry pokes and prods at each mystery until he ultimately ferrets out the real killer in the courtroom under the resentful nose of hard-headed prosecutor, Hamilton Burger (William Talman.) Watching Perry close in on the real killer is a joy to behold, but Mason is at his best when he, along with Della and Paul, are sneaking around and investigating evidence, often under the suspicious eye of their police nemesis, Lt. Tragg (Ray Collins.)All but one of the episodes in the first season are adaptations of the earlier Gardner novels. The plots may be predictable where the climax is concerned, but Gardner (a criminal lawyer himself), fills his plots with genuine legal intricacies that give this crime fiction a feeling of sincere authenticity that is certainly not felt in later TV legal reincarnations. It's also noteworthy that, unlike most other series, Perry Mason was at his best and most edgy early on in the first two seasons. Here, Mason would often skirt legal ethics in order to protect his client from injustice. This would often result in the questioning of Mason's conduct and character by Tragg and Burger, as evidenced in "The Case of the Demure Defendant," "The Case of the Sunbather's Diary," and "The Case of the Moth-Eaten Mink." In later seasons, Perry mellowed a bit and his relationship with the other side became more amicable.These disks are sadly lacking in extra content, but the audio and visual restoration alone, along with the uncut 52-minute episodes, make both volumes of the first season worth the price. If you're a fan of good classic detective fiction, or just good legal drama, Perry mason is a must for your collection.
summary: Perry Mason: Superior Legal Drama Remains Timeless

reviewText: Raymond Burr IS Perry Mason. The man is a incapable of bad acting in any form. I have been watching eight seasons of Perry Mason as well as his Ironside series. I used to HATE black and white tv (which I grew up with) but I find it doesn't matter when watching this series. The stories are great, the courtroom scenes are brilliant and Perry always gets a confession from the 'murderer' and BEFORE a trial even begins! It would be laughable but for some reason it's not!This is the third time I have watched this series (can you believe it?) and I never get tired of seeing Burr perform his magic. With 'Della' as his right arm and "Paul Drake' as his left he's totally equipped for any situation.During one of the special features (there aren't many) it was noted that at times Burr read q cards but he was so adept that he never let the audience know what he was reading or doing. It's no wonder for he had so many long monologues and a lot of dialogue each week.If you are a lover of court drama, mystery but no outward violence, no blood and guts as there is now - just a story and a 'bad' guy and Perry and his team-this is one drama you don't want to miss. Probably the best court drama ever made and as much as I love the Law and Order's - Perry wins the prize - year after year after year for nine years - and then many years later the team (some had died - Tragg, Paul Drake) was asked to do some 2 hour movies and they were great as well.Sigh--I wish I could have met the man in person for he is truly an icon of the highest order and I'm sure I'll be dragging out the DVD's in another few years and watch them all over again!Sherrie H.

reviewText: A California lawyer who turned author, Erle Stanley Gardner began writing Perry Mason novels in the 1930's, and continued for about 40 years.  Mason was a most unusual attorney, proactively investigating, getting involved in open cases, at times skirting the law, and specializing in homicide cases.  The adventures of the intrepid lawyer were featured in movies and on radio, before coming to television in 1957.With well established characters, Perry Mason benefitted from superb casting, with Raymond Burr as Mason, Barbara Hale as superloyal secretary Della Street, William Hopper as droll private investigator Paul Drake, William Talman as the combative Hamilton Burger, and Ray Collins as the determined homicide detective Lt. Tragg.While Gardner had indeed 'laid the foundation', it was this magnificent cast and the series writers, that got things correct from the start, and made the formula a prime time success for many years.Mason did not spend his time in an office behind a desk.  He was more like a detective, often at the front line of the action, working with the help of Della and Paul to discover the truth, staying one step ahead of the police, and doing whatever it took to solve the case.The episodes from the first season are mostly adaptations of the novels Gardner had completed up to that time.  The cases are usually complex, demanding the viewer's attention if they hope to follow along, and figure out the solution.  Those that have read Gardner's novels might already know the solution, but the well executed performances still make for interesting viewing.  Similarly, the episodes are very rewatchable, even when the culprit is known.  Episodes typically featured talented actors in the guest cast, and the stories often reflect the variety of settings in southern California, with Mason's clientele come from all levels of society.While the entire regular cast was stellar, Raymond Burr was magnificent as Perry Mason, and truly made the character his own.  Raymond Burr is inextricably linked with the character, and when in 1985 Burr again resumed the role of the iconoclastic lawyer, it insured that additional generations of viewers would forever indentify Burr with Perry Mason.This set contains a nice slice from Mason's caseload, with nineteen of the thirty nine episodes in the first season.  Mason's proactive approach, and courtroom theatrics, may not have been too realistic, but it certainly makes for extremely compelling, classic television.

reviewText: Raymond Burr played Perry Mason for 12 seasons on the original Perry Mason TV series before turning his attention to becoming Ironsides and then finally back to Perry Mason in a series of TV movies.  The character of Perry Mason appeared in several movies back in the 1930's and 1940's (played by actors Warren William, Ricardo Cortez and Donald Woods) but author Erle Stanley Gardner was never happy with the  way Mason was portrayed.  So when the TV series came about in 1957, Gardner made sure it was done right.  And here are the first 19 episodes, many adapted from his own novels, with Burr in fine form as Mason with a great supporting cast.  I really enjoyed watching these episodes which started the whole series off in top form.  (It was interesting to see how they introduced us to each character in the first show!)

reviewText: I've read many of the reviews for this box set of 19 episodes of one of the all-time greats of television history, Perry Mason, and although I agree with most of them (great show, excellent picture quality, etc), I can't say I agree with those who moan about the 'high price.' I do understand that in order to obtain the full first season we must purchase TWO box sets instead of one, which makes the first-season cost around 50 bucks (new sets can be purchased for around $25 if you shop around a bit), but even at $60 it's a bargain when you put it into proper perspective.Let's examine some other box sets of popular television shows. Let's take a single season set of The Flintstones as an example. At first glance, it seems like a better deal than the Perry Mason box sets. One entire season is around $30-35 per set for approximately 25 episodes (the first couple of seasons have gone down in price now that they've been around a while and the newer seasons are about 35 bucks or so. Taking that into consideration, it's safe to assume that the PM sets will also go down in price once subsequent sets are released). What you must bear in mind, of course, is that although you get more episodes of The Flintstones for around the same price as one of the PM first season sets, The Flintstones was only a half hour show while PM is an hour. That would make 19 episodes of PM equate to 38 episodes of The Flintstones, in terms of time, but since, for about the same price, you only get 25 episodes of TF, the PM sets are a better deal overall. Not to mention what a GREAT show Perry Mason was/is!The show itself is worth five stars easily, however I give the DVD set only four due to the lack of any extras. Surely a short documentary or interview could have been squeezed onto the last disc, which contains only three episodes. That may be nitpicking, but lesser shows than PM have had better packaging as far as extras go. That may seem like quibbling to some, but most people nowadays are willing to spend a couple more dollars in order to get a few extras, however to some who think the price is already too high, I can understand the concern Paramount may have had in splurging to produce extra features that would raise the price of the sets. There is some good regarding the packaging in that Paramount decided to do the right thing by producing one-sided discs as opposed to the double-sided 'flipper discs' that Universal is notorious for. It is well-known that flipper discs are much more prone to picture-freezing, skipping and damage (it's much easier to smudge or scratch a disc when BOTH sides have data than when only one does) than one-sided discs, so I thank Paramount for that foresight. That alone probably makes this set worth a couple bucks more than the offerings that feature flippers.Lastly, to the people who have pointed out that, at this price, it would cost around $600 to own the complete set of ten seasons (1957-1966), yes that seems pricey, but how many television shows boasted anywhere near 271 hour-long episodes? Precious few, to be sure.I hope this helps to put the price of these sets into perspective. In the long run, I believe they are a better deal than most TV box sets. Peace.
summary: Please stop whining about the price!
